_exec_summary.SummaryText:
gement information and to provide guidelines for employee involvement in the development and implementation of Process Safety Management. Process Safety Information organizes the documentation and availability of written process safety information, pertaining to hazards of the chemicals used, the technology, and equipment covered in the process. The management system identifies the currently available information and establishes guidelines for producing
additional information. Process Hazards Analysis provides the structure for identifying, evaluating, and controlling processes involving anhydrous ammonia. Process Hazard Analysis Team defines the selected employees who shall participate in the formal PSM program activities based on their familiarity with the ammonia refrigeration system. Operating Procedures defines the format, structure, and change method for specific procedures developed for operating the ammonia refrigeration system. These procedures and practices are critical in maintaining a safe
operation. Training defines the requirements and establishes the process for initial and follow-up operations training for employees working in hazardous areas. The material is then developed to meet the specific training requirements, and must include verification of training and employee training documentation. Contractor Control organizes contractor safety programs in the plant and ensures that the critical aspects of working in a hazardous area is included in the program. This includes specific record keeping requirements associated with contractors working in hazardous areas. Pre-startup Safety Review provides guidelines for reviewing new or modified hazardous facilities prior to startup. These guidelines require that the facility is installed in accordance with design specifications, confirms that the Process Safety Information is updated and accurate, operating procedures are in place, and training is completed prior to startup. Mechanical Integrity organizes an

d documents, through the establishment of procedures, existing maintenance,
testing, quality assurance, and inspection practices to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment. Hot Work Permits enhances and implements existing hot work practices and permits used in the ammonia refrigeration system areas. The system ensures that the procedures are adequate to provide proper protection in a hazardous chemical area. Management of Change establishes and implements written procedures for managing all changes to the
process. This management system includes provisions for ensuring that the changes are correctly performed, documented, training is conducted, and reflected in the applicable Process Safety Information. Process Safety Incident Investigation enhances existing procedures and practices to prevent recurrence of process safety incidents. Emergency Planning and Response clarifies and confirms the existing facility plans containing complete provisions for responding to any emergencies involving anhydrous ammonia. Compliance Audits establishes the protocol for conducting process safety audits every three years, including the written report and documentation of deficiency corrections. Trade Secrets documents guidelines for open exchange of safety-critical information and protection of company secrets.

Stahl-Meyer Foods, Madison, FL operates an ammonia refrigeration system to produce
space cooling, product cooling, and process equipment cooling.
The Stahl-Meyer Foods refrigeration system is designed to provide:
Operating flexibility (through availability of multiple operating equipment combinations);
Efficiency of operations (through the use of operating pressures commensurate with the degree of cooling required and alternative fuel / energy equipment); Safety performance (through safety systems that can shutdown the system and minimal use of ammonia liquid pumps, utilizing instead the pressure differentials established in the system to move liquid refrigerant); and
Consistency of operation, utilizing ammonia system operators to operate, and modulate refrigeration equipment as conditions require.
Emergency Systems
The ammonia refrigeration system has several safety features. In the event of a liquid ammonia leak, the king valves (outlet of the high pressure liquid receiver) can be closed manually to prevent flow of ammonia liquid to downstream equipment. The system can be shutdown by the 
 emergency stop stations located in and outside the engine room.  In addition, ammonia sensors located in the engine room. The facility is equipped with a sprinkler system.
Response Capabilities
The facility evacuates only and relies on the Madison Fire Department and the ammonia contractor for response.
Ammonia System Summary
Major equipment components include:
6 Compressors
58 Evaporators
2 Evaporative Condensers
1 Purger
3 Liquid Recirculators
6 Ammonia Pumps
1 High Pressure Liquid Receiver
2 Brine Chillers
Ammonia inventory: 15,357 lbs.
Ammonia system operators: One operator.
Ammonia System Contractor: American Refrigeration
Process Safety Management/Risk Management Program Description
The facility has a fully implemented process safety management / risk management program including:
